author: Rajiv Tangri
title: Social Spider Web of Decision
description: How do we diversify and increase participation?

assessments.note: The proposal offers some interesting ideas and concepts that would address the challenge, such as the referral scheme (buddy tag system) and mentoring of new users. It still reads only as a top level concept though and would benefit from further refinement and more details to become a executable proposal.
Interesting idea, however it is not very well detailed.

Three out of the four elements of the proposal focus on outreach and attracting new community members, so the proposal would have probably been better place in the Proposer Outreach or Value Onboarding challenges. The underlying assumption on which this proposal is built is that we should give up anonymity, but my sense is that a lot of the members in our community value their anonymity.

The proposal helps to push distributed decision making and helps to increase participation. The idea about a TAG-System sounds very interesting and could help the communtiy-network effect grow. On the other hand we're in the field of blockchain and crypto and loads of people like to keep their privacy.

A Buddy system to train 6 new incoming persons and rewards for doing so is a unique idea. The social media campaign and AI bots do not have a clear utility. The Cardano community has an immense presence, therefore the Ad campaign does not seems to be an ideal solution.

The proposal effectively contributes to addressing the challenge but it could have been a little more descriptive on how they see the communications and engagement strategy ultimately affecting community (distributed) decision making. We may be able to imagine how the communications and engagement strategy may contribute to that but it should have been the responsibility of the proponent to help us visualize it. In my opinion, the proposal is promising.

It's not clear what experience the proposer has that would help him achieve this, specially for the 3rd section of data analyses and AI automation section. It also doesn't seem feasible for the proposer to set-up a referral scheme, mentoring, data analyses and creation of a video message board on his own. The plan lacks many details e.g. which social media will be used to advertise, what type of adverts, how the buddy tag system will be implemented, who will sponsor and mentor new recruits, what type of data analyses techniques you will use, etc.
The budget allocation is also very briefly described, for example you say "Social Media targeted Ad Campaigns- 5000" you should detail how many adds you intend to lunch and in which platforms.
The plan lacks concrete details and the proposer doesn't have any stated technical background to produce a solution.

The proposer states that he has a background in healthcare and education, but no information is presented to verify this. More so this proposal is marketing and functionality oriented, yet no credentials or information is given regarding that. Furthermore the proposal includes the development of an AI to parse community information, yet no concrete plan is presented about how would this be achieved. Who would actually implemented it, the budget for that part seems extremely low.

The experience of the proposer doesn't fit a 100% the qualifications that are needed for such a proposal. The goal is appartently to outsource a lot of tasks but wouldn't it be better to focus on one thing and do it right instead of trying to achieve several different goals?  It would be good to actually first gather a team or at least one or two persons so voter see that you are committed. There is a sensible butget and a fair allocation of funds.

The proposer claims limited experience in software development and has not identified developers capable of developing an AI bot. It is a difficult proposition to implement such a complex system on such a small budget.

The proposal does not require that the proponent demonstrate the skills to achieve implementation on their own. Instead, the proposal suggests relying on in-house experience and outsourcing. Given that the realm of the proposal is established on social media, the existing technical experience related to Cardano should be more than enough to pursue the project satisfactorily. The project would benefit from clearly identifying (or hiring) someone with the demonstrated experience, inside of the Cardano community or in the professional market. If I could I would have given the proposal a 3.5 (or a little bit more).

There are no milestones presented on how the concepts would be developed. There is no criteria of success presented e.g. minimum amount of participants referred via buddy tag system and number of users brought in via adds.
There is not enough detail on what would actually be produced.

Setting aside the elements of the proposal, there's no clear plan as to how those elements will be actually implemented. No clear roadmap dates are given. No KPIs. No metrics by which to asses progress.There's no description of the team/person who would actually implement the proposal. Having video content attached to proposals would help with decision making for sure, but isn't attaching videos already an option for proposals who want to do it, why would we need a separate platform.

There is a lot of informations on what the proposer likes to achieve but not that much about how to achieve it. A more detailed roadmap would benefit. If you compare the proposal to others you can see what I mean.

The proposal has sufficient information; however, it will be difficult to audit the progress of AI bot performance and the social media campaign. There is also a lack of info concerning the development of the solution.

Given that the reality of the proposal is, for the most part, established social media and other collaborative platforms, it should be easy to create a detailed audit for its implementation. Thanks to the proponent for their contribution.

solution: To build participation we need to build trust by utilizing social media and group gatherings (online and off).
